conbody.p: Collection operators enable you to evaluate expressions over collections or objects. The operators include ANY, EVERY, ARRAY, FIRST, EXISTS, IN, and WITHIN.
conbody.codeblock: exists-expression | in-expression | within-expression | ANY | EVERY | ARRAY | FIRST

section.title: ANY Operator
section.codeblock: ANY field1 ( IN | WITHIN ) in_within_expression1 [ , field2 ( IN | WITHIN ) in_within_expression2 ] * SATISFIES condition END

dlentry.dd: ANY is a range predicate that tests a Boolean condition over the elements or attributes of a collection, object, or objects.
IN sets the search range to include only the top level of the collection in in_within_expression.
This ranges through the top level and all sub-levels of the collection in in_within_expression.
An array, object, or collection to search in or within.
This encompasses the condition which is the equivalent of a WHERE clause.
If at least one item in the array satisfies the ANY expression, then it returns TRUE. Otherwise, it returns FALSE.

section.p: Example 1: The following query retrieves all flights that are direct (less than 1 stopover).
section.codeblock: SELECT schedule, stops FROM `travel-sample` WHERE ANY flight IN schedule SATISFIES stops < 1 END LIMIT 1;
section.p: Sometimes the conditions you want to filter need to be applied to the arrays nested inside the document. The SATISFIES keyword is used to specify the filter condition. The expression after the ANY clause allows us to assign an identifier to an element in the array that we are searching through.
section.note: The SOME and ANY operators perform the same function and can be used interchangeably.

section.title: EVERY Operator
section.codeblock: EVERY field1 ( IN | WITHIN ) in_within_expression1 [ , field2 ( IN | WITHIN ) in_within_expression2 ] * SATISFIES condition END

dlentry.dd: EVERY is a range predicate that tests a Boolean condition over the elements or attributes of a collection, object, or objects.
IN sets the search range to include only the top level of the collection in in_within_expression.
WITHIN sets the query range to include the top level and all descendants of the collection in in_within_expression.
An array, object, or collection to search in or within.
This encompasses the condition which is the equivalent of a WHERE clause.

If every array element satisfies the EVERY expression, then it returns TRUE. Otherwise, it returns FALSE.
If the array is empty, it returns TRUE.
The EVERY operator returns TRUE if all items meet the condition.

section.p: Example 2: The following query is almost identical to Example 2 except EVERY is used instead of ANY. This query scans all contacts and returns the name of any contact that has children over the age of 10. The result tells us that out of all of the contacts only 'ian' has children who are all over the age 10.
section.codeblock: SELECT SUM(schedule), schedule, stops FROM `travel-sample` WHERE EVERY flight IN schedule SATISFIES stops < 1 END LIMIT 1;
section.p: Sometimes the conditions you want to filter need to be applied to the arrays nested inside the document. The SATISFIES keyword is used to specify the filter condition. The expression after the EVERY clause allows us to assign a name to an element in the array that we are searching through.
section.codeblock: SELECT fname, children FROM tutorial WHERE EVERY child IN tutorial.children SATISFIES child.age > 10 END

section.title: ARRAY Operator
section.codeblock: ARRAY expression FOR variable1 ( IN | WITHIN ) expression [ , variable2 ( IN | WITHIN ) expression2 ] * [ ( WHEN condition) ] END

dlentry.dd: The ARRAY operator lets you map and filter the elements or attributes of a collection, object, or objects.
It evaluates to an array of the operand expression, that satisfies the WHEN clause, if provided.

section.title: IN Operator
section.p:
Description IN sets the search range to include only the top level of the collection in in_expression.
Arguments
NOT Used to describe the opposite of the IN operator; that is, to exclude certain items.
in_expression The expression
Return Value The IN operator evaluates to TRUE if the right-side value is an array and directly contains the left-side value. The NOT IN operator evaluates to TRUE if the right-side value is an array and does not directly contain the left-side value.
Example 6a: List INSELECT

section.title: WITHIN Operator
section.p:
Description WITHIN sets the search range to include the top level and descendants of the collection in within_expression.
Arguments
NOT Used to describe the opposite of the IN operator; that is, to exclude certain items.
within_expression The expression
Return Value The IN operator evaluates to TRUE if the right-side value contains the left-side value as a child or descendant. The NOT WITHIN operator evaluates to TRUE if the right-side value does not contain the left-side value as a child or descendant.
